ARABIC: فَتَوَلَّىٰ بِرُكْنِهِۦ وَقَالَ سَٰحِرٌ أَوْ مَجْنُونٌ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: But he turned away with his forces, saying, 'A magician or a madman!'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: But he turned to his counsellors, and said: "He is a magician or lunatic."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: But Pharaoh turned away, showing arrogance on account of his power, and said (about Moses): “He is either a sorcerer or a madman.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: The Pharaoh and his forces turned away from him, saying, "He is either a magician or an insane person".
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: In response, he turned away along with his army and said, “He is a magician or a madman.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: But (he) turned away along with his hosts, and said: "A sorcerer or a madman."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: But he turned away with his forces and said: A magician or a mad man.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: but he turned his back, with his court, saying, 'A sorcerer, or a man possessed!'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: But he withdrew (confiding) in his might, and said: A wizard or a madman.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: But he turned his back, he and his courtiers, and said, "This is a sorcerer or a madman."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Then he turned away with his court, and said: a magician or a madman.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: But he turned away assured of his might, and said, ‘A magician or a crazy man!’
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: But (Pharaoh) turned back with his Chiefs, and said, "A sorcerer, or one possessed!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: But [Fir'aun (Pharaoh)] turned away (from Belief in might) along with his hosts, and said: "A sorcerer, or a madman."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: but he turned his back with his Assembly, saying: 'He is (either) a sorcerer or a mad man'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: But he turned away with his warlords, and said, “A sorcerer or a madman.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: But he turned away with his supporters and said," A magician or a madman."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [51:39] but he turned away, he rejected belief, to his supports (bi-ruknihi), his hosts, [so called] because to him they are like a support [rukn], saying, to Moses that he [Moses] was: ‘A sorcerer, or a madman!’
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (But he withdrew (confiding) in his might) pharaoh refused to believe in the proof or in Moses, relying instead on his troops, (and said: A wizard or a madman) bewitched.
